awd_titl_txt: CDS&E: D3SC: The Dark Reaction Project:  A machine-learning approach to exploring structural diversity in solid state synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award receives funds from the Division of Materials Research, the Chemistry Division and the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure. This award supports research and education that uses data-centric methods to enable the prediction of metal oxide compounds with desired properties. Organically-templated metal oxides have a tremendous degree of structural diversity and compositional flexibility. This allows chemists to tune the structures, properties, and symmetries of these compounds to optimize their performance in specific applications that include catalysis, molecular sieving, gas adsorption, and nonlinear optics.  However, new compounds are typically created by a trial-and-error procedure, and creating novel compounds with specific structures is a grand challenge in solid state chemistry.  This project will develop artificial intelligence techniques for computers called machine learning techniques that can be used to predict the conditions for chemical reactions that will increase structural diversity and lead to specific structural features.  This project will also develop machine learning techniques that generate human-readable explanations about the formation mechanism, which will be tested in the laboratory.
 
The primary impact of this project will be to decrease the amount of time and to lower the cost of discovering new materials with specific structural features, which in turn help bring new materials for applications to market more quickly.  This project is an example of a collaboration among synthetic chemists, computational chemists, and computer scientists and as a model it may be directly transferred to a wide range of disciplines and avenues of investigation. Undergraduate student research opportunities and curricular developments will be involved throughout the project, thus contributing to the scientific workforce.
 
TECHNICAL SUMMARY 
This award receives funds from the Division of Materials Research, the Chemistry Division and the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure. This award supports research and education that uses data-centric methods to enable the prediction of metal oxide compounds with desired properties. Hydrothermal synthesis is widely used to create new metal oxide materials with a wide range of functional properties and applications.  This project will advance the field by developing software infrastructure for associating the results of X-ray diffraction experiments with individual reactions, extracting structural outcome descriptors from this data, and then determining the extent to which these structural outcomes can be predicted from reaction description data.  This will be achieved by developing structural outcome descriptors for geometric properties, non-covalent interaction properties, and electron-density properties, then building machine learning models that correlate these outcomes to reaction conditions, and finally testing the quality of these predictions experimentally.  Active learning and auditable and interpretable models will be incorporated into the workflows to help synthetic chemists select better (more insightful/novel) reactions in an interactive fashion.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:  New materials are needed to advance many types of technologies, but the typical discovery process relies on a tedious trial-and-error process. We have previously shown how a comprehensive data set of experimental results (including both success and failure) is needed to  train machine learning models that predict reaction outcomes comparably to human experts. This has motivated our work to develop new ways of collecting, storing, and sharing a complete record of the experimental process.  Using these datasets, we were able to identify systematic biases in human-planned experiments that artificially restrict the predictions of machine learning models.  In general, human-planned experiments have the signatures of cognitive shortcuts, such as selecting the most popular reagent choices or reaction conditions.  This artificially limits the performance of machine learning algorithms compared to other ways of generating experiment plans.  To account for the selective reporting and biases in experimental data, we have developed neural-network based machine learning methods that can partially accommodate for these flaws.  One approach focuses on predicting general types of structural outcomes of the resulting compounds.  Another approach develops a generative model for predicting the statistical distribution of compositions of hypothetical compounds by enforcing cycle-consistency constraints.  We have validated our computational work by experimentally synthesizing new compounds. We also contributed to the development of new machine-representations of solid state structures, which can serve as an enabling technology for generate AI approaches.  We published 17 papers describing this work.  


Broader Impacts:  During this project we have trained 19 undergraduate students, 2 masters students, and 1 postdoctoral fellow in this combination of data science and synthetic chemistry, contributing to the scientific workforce.  We have developed freely-available teaching materials that enable instructors to incorporate machine learning methods into their existing undergraduate coursework and pedagogical laboratories.   These include: (i) developing a new course for first-year undergraduate students that teaches an introduction  computer programming in Python  and its application to statistical-mechanics based introductory treatment of chemical thermodynamics, equilibrium, electrochemistry and kinetics; (ii) contributing code to a free online cheminformatics textbook; (iii) developing laboratories that introduce third-year undergraduate students to machine learning and feature extraction in the context of infrared spectroscopy interpretation and UV/vis spectroscopy, respectively.
